Generation I.Red: Found in fields and mountains. Mistaking them for boulders, people often step or trip on them.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: Found in fields and mountains. Mistaking them for boulders, people often step or trip on them.
Generation I.Yellow: Commonly found near mountain trails, etc. If you step on one by accident, it gets angry.
Generation I.Stadium: When traveling uphill, if it encounters a raised step, it cleverly hoists itself up and over using its two arms.

Generation II.Gold: Most people may not notice, but a closer look should reveal that there are many Geodude around.
Generation II.Silver: It uses its arms to steadily climb steep mountain paths. It swings its fists around if angered.
Generation II.Crystal: Proud of their sturdy bodies, they bash against each other in a contest to prove whose is harder.
Generation II.Stadium 2: Most people may not notice, but a closer look should reveal that there are many Geodude around. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) It uses its arms to steadily climb steep mountain paths. It swings its fists around if angered. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: The longer a Geodude lives, the more its edges are chipped and worn away, making it more rounded in appearance. However, this Pok é mon 's heart will remain hard, craggy, and rough always.
Generation III.Sapphire: When Geodude sleeps deeply, it buries itself halfway into the ground. It will not awaken even if hikers step on it unwittingly. In the morning, this Pok é mon rolls downhill in search of food.
Generation III.Emerald: It climbs mountain paths using only the power of its arms. Because they look just like boulders lining paths, hikers may step on them without noticing.
Generation III.FireRed: Its round form makes it easy to pick up. Some people have used them to hurl at each other in a snowball fight.
Generation III.LeafGreen: Found in fields and mountains. Mistaking them for boulders, people often step or trip on them.

Generation IV.Diamond: Many live on mountain trails and remain half buried while keeping an eye on climbers.
Generation IV.Pearl: It is impossible to distinguish from rocks. It slams against others in contests of hardness.
Generation IV.Platinum: At rest, it looks just like a rock. Carelessly stepping on it will make it swing its fists angrily.
Generation IV.HeartGold: Most people may not notice, but a closer look should reveal that there are many Geodude around.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: It uses its arms to steadily climb steep mountain paths. It swings its fists around if angered.

Generation V.Black: At rest, it looks just like a rock. Carelessly stepping on it will make it swing its fists angrily.
Generation V.White: At rest, it looks just like a rock. Carelessly stepping on it will make it swing its fists angrily.
Generation V.Black 2: At rest, it looks just like a rock. Carelessly stepping on it will make it swing its fists angrily.
Generation V.White 2: At rest, it looks just like a rock. Carelessly stepping on it will make it swing its fists angrily.

Generation VI.X: Found in fields and mountains. Mistaking them for boulders, people often step or trip on them.
Generation VI.Y: It is impossible to distinguish from rocks. It slams against others in contests of hardness.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: The longer a Geodude lives, the more its edges are chipped and worn away, making it more rounded in appearance. However, this Pokémon's heart will remain hard, craggy, and rough always.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: When Geodude sleeps deeply, it buries itself halfway into the ground. It will not awaken even if hikers step on it unwittingly. In the morning, this Pokémon rolls downhill in search of food.

Generation VII.Sun: Its body is a magnetic stone. Iron sand attaches firmly to the portions of its body that are particularly magnetic.
Generation VII.Moon: If you accidentally step on a Geodude sleeping on the ground, you'll hear a crunching sound and feel a shock ripple through your entire body.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: If you mistake it for a rock and step on it, it will headbutt you in anger. In addition to the pain, it will also zap you with a shock.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: Geodude compete against each other with headbutts. The iron sand on their heads will stick to whichever one has stronger magnetism.
Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: Its stone head is imbued with electricity and magnetism. If you carelessly step on one, you'll be in for a painful shock.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: Its stone head is imbued with electricity and magnetism. If you carelessly step on one, you'll be in for a painful shock.

Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: Many live on mountain trails and remain	half-buried while keeping an eye on climbers.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It is impossible to distinguish from rocks. It slams against others in contests of toughness.
Generation VIII.Legends: Arceus: Makes its home in mountainous regions, using its arms to climb along harsh mountain roads. Can be troublesome—carelessly kicking one will cause it to fly into a rage and chase after you.

Generation IX.Scarlet: Its body is a magnetic stone. Iron sand attaches firmly to the portions of its body that are particularly magnetic.
Generation IX.Violet: If you step on a Geodude sleeping on the ground, you’ll hear a zapping sound and feel a tingling shock throughout your entire body.
